Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Chian black-figured Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior glazed black; added red band between two faded added white bands; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of parts of siren to left (neck, hair and curlicue, wing and scaley body with red.
Curator's comments: The sherd may join British Museum 1924,1201.352 and Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR97.1894. The sherd belongs to the group of Chian black figured vases bearing Laconising features. According to Williams, the kylix is by the same painter as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.133.2 and AN1896-1908-G.133.6, whom he has identified as the Sirens Painter. The Sirens Painter pieces most closely resemble those by the Boreads Painter, primarily because of the single pomegranate band on the tondo of the Oxford kylix.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 154-5, p. 324, no. 1465)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 130-2, fig. 20, note 67)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0875) (phase 2)
